Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: The Role of Tradition in Cultural Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the supervision of Dr. Neil Norman of the College of William & Mary, Madeleine Bassett will undertake archaeological research to study the impact of pastoralist political economies on the timing and nature of Islamic Period religious change in the Horn of Africa. The Islamic Period (ca. AD 800-1400) marked a time of transformation in the Horn of Africa: In the span of a few centuries, urban centers emerged along the Somali coast and thousands of ancestral Somali pastoralists converted to Islam. Previous scholarship on religious change has centered on large-scale, sedentary agricultural societies. Africanist scholars, for example, have effectively demonstrated the importance of Islam in the history of eastern Africa and the Indian Ocean World, focusing predominantly on the sedentary societies of the Swahili coast. Through the archaeology of pastoralist settlements in Djibouti, this project focuses instead on seasonally mobile pastoralist societies, and the ways in which their economic networks, political systems, and local ecologies defined the conditions and limits of religious transformation. Ultimately, this research seeks to answer two related questions: How did local actors influence or participate in the process (i.e., timing and nature) of religious change in Djibouti? Specifically, how did local actors shape the creation and use of religious spaces through time? This project is well positioned to address these questions because it utilizes archaeological methodologies that allow the systematic collection and analysis of material evidence related to religious practices across space and time. This project is significant because it will shed new light on the process of Islamic Period religious change in the Horn of Africa, and more broadly on the nature of religious change among mobile, pastoralist societies. The issue of religion and religious change is relevant, and often violence related, in many regions of the world today and the results of this research have the potential to shed interpretive light on current day processes.

The project will examine how and when Islam spread to seasonally mobile pastoralist communities living along the Somali Coast by mapping the organization and evolution of religious infrastructures across pastoralist landscapes. It will be conducted in eastern Djibouti, an important area in the spread of Islam from the Arabian Peninsula through the Horn of Africa. Under the supervision of Dr. Norman, Bassett will examine the spatial and diachronic patterning of Islamic Period structures and artifacts at a large, pastoralist seasonal aggregation site in the Ambouli River drainage of eastern Djibouti. This project will test the hypothesis that pastoralist political economies - and the social and religious institutions at their center - influenced how pastoralists integrated Islam into their daily routines and seasonal settlement practices. As the first study in eastern Africa to date pre-Islamic and Islamic-Period stone structures using a combination of OSL (Optically Stimulated Luminescence) and AMS radiocarbon dating methods, this project will develop the first detailed chronology for the integration of Islamic architectural elements into archaeological sites along the Somali coast. By establishing a solid chronological sequence for Islamic architectural elements, this project will bolster understandings of when and how eastern Africa's rural pastoralist societies converted to Islam and improve general chronologies for the spread of Islam in Africa. In so doing, this project will make significant contributions to anthropological theory by extending the scope of research on religious change to include pastoral societies and their political economies. Finally, one broader impact of this project will be the creation of a database of information about pre-Islamic and Islamic Period archaeological sites and structures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the archaeology of pastoralist sites in southeastern Djibouti to understand the subsistence and settlement strategies of the seasonally-mobile pastoral populations that lived there during and after the Islamic Period—a critical period in the region’s history. Djibouti is a tiny country that is situated between Somaliland and Eritrea, at the convergence of the Red Sea and the Indian Ocean. The Islamic Period (ca. AD800-1400) marked a time of economic, sociocultural, and religious transformation for the populations that once inhabited southeastern Djibouti, and the eastern Horn of Africa more broadly. In the span of a few centuries, urban centers emerged along the Somali Coast and thousands of ancestral Somali pastoralists converted to Islam. Scholars have effectively demonstrated the importance of Islam in the history of eastern Africa and the Indian Ocean World, although much of this scholarship has focused on the sedentary societies of the Swahili Coast. This project shifts focus to the Islamic Period history of the Somali Coast, and to the more mobile, pastoralist populations that lived there by documenting a range of pastoralist sites and landscapes in Southeastern Djibouti.

Using traditional and “digital survey” methods, this project identified dozens of previously unrecorded archaeological sites, and in so doing developed understandings of the territorial ranges, settlement patterns, and subsistence strategies of Islamic-Period populations. Through an analysis of faunal materials (primarily marine mollusks) recovered from a sample of these sites, this study determined that pastoralist populations in the region practiced a mixed subsistence strategy that included herding and seasonal shellfish gathering. Analysis of lithics (e.g., obsidian and chalcedony), locally-made earthenware ceramics, imported ceramics (e.g., Chinese porcelains, various ware types that were were likely imported from the Arabian Peninsula and the Indian subcontinent), and imported glass objects (e.g., drawn glass beads, glass bracelet fragments) suggests that these same pastoralist populations also engaged in local- and regional-scale trade networks during their seasonal rounds. As such, and building upon archaeological studies of pastoralist societies across the Horn of Africa, this study provides an important comparative example of how pastoral subsistence and settlement strategies articulated with Islamic Period economic activities.

From August through December of 2019, fieldwork was conducted using various methods of landscape archaeology. The project brought together multiple lines of evidence, including geospatial data (generated through the systematic mapping of archaeological features, sites, and landscapes), data obtained through the object- and attribute-level analysis of artifacts and faunal materials, and data obtained through the radiometric dating of archaeological materials. Through an analysis of these lines of evidence, the project determined that many of the sites in the study area—in particular, the CB-sites (located in the interior) and the CL-sites (located along the coast)—articulated within a regional landscape (or territory) in which populations rotated seasonally between the coast and the interior. Seasonal movement likely afforded access to different types of seasonally-available resources (e.g., grazing lands for herd animals in the interior, shellfish along the coast), as well as access to emerging global trade networks along the coast. 

Products generated over the course of this research project (including an ArcGIS database of archaeological sites in the study area and beyond) will serve as a resource for future research, as well as a heritage inventory tool for Djiboutian preservation stakeholders, the Djiboutian government, and international organizations dedicated to heritage protection (e.g., Smithsonian Cultural Rescue Initiative (SCRI), U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield (USCBS)).
